column4: hey guys, i'm having a problem with my new laptop. I have specified that while on battery power, when i close the lid the computer should enter sleep mode. however, when i open the lid again, the screen does not turn back on. pressing keys, moving the mouse, pressing the power button, nothing works.
I've heard a lot of people saying that hibernate can be iffy.
Its not hibernation, it's sleep. if it helps, i'm using intel 8.10 drivers running beryl
yes, and i have no lack of ram on this laptop.
i know that hibernation won't work for me since i forgot that the swap has to be more than the ram.

It might be beryl related, you could always try switching back to meta-city temporary...But, personally speaking, I have found that both are generally iffy, and I have my machine set just to shut off the monitor.

i'll take that into consideration. this is my first laptop, and overall i'm extremely pleased with ubuntu's performance on a laptop. the only thing i had to do was reconfigure panel-applets so i could specify the governor for the cpu scaling.
that and the modem doesn't work, but i expected that.
I've never played with CPU scaling, how does that affect your setup?
i'll try sleeping with metacity, and i'll let you know how it goes.

instead of ondemand scaling, which goes up and down madly, i want to be able to set a definite limit on the speed of the cpu, so i can squeeze some extra battery life out. i have it locked on the minimum clock speed right now.
I have to run in a hot second, but like I said, I've heard it is iffy
perhaps it's an issue with intel's drivers.
